: : CIVIL COURTS OF FIRST INSTANCE: REDUCTION OF BACKLOG 4219/'13 6. . ( . (The Hon. Ajith P. Perera) - (2):
(i) separately, the steps taken by the Ministry of Justice in the years 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2013 to reduce the backlog of the Civil Courts of First Instance; and
(ii) whether judicial activities in the Civil Courts of First Instance are carried out in a considerable speed?
(b) If not, why? ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem - Minister of Justice) Hon. Deputy Speaker, the Answer is as follows:

(a) (i) The Ministry has taken a number of initiatives to reduce the backlog of civil cases during the years 2010 to 2013. Three Civil Appellate High Courts and 24 District Courts were established with a view to reducing the backlog of cases. I table* Annex I. Presently 20 Civil Appellate High Courts are functioning. Several Training Programmes for District Judges have been conducted by the Judge's Institute with a view to enhancing their capacity and to expedite civil cases.

Three hundred and twenty six Mediation Boards function in the Island and this helps both to prevent matters going to courts and also to reduce the backlog of cases. Further, the Ministry has introduced the 5S system in a number of courts with a view to enhancing the efficiency of court registries.
Twenty four Legal Aid Centres were established during the years 2010 to 2013. I table* Annex II.

In 2013, the Government Analyst's Department was shifted to a new building equipped with state-of-the-art technology in order to enhance the capacity of the officers and expedite the issuing of reports which contribute in great part to the expeditious disposal of cases.
We have also finalized an amendment to the Civil Procedure Code to introduce Pre-trial Proceedings. The draft has been submitted to Cabinet.
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Hon. Deputy Speaker, there are a few reasons. The Hon. Member is also aware that this issue was raised

several times at the Consultative Committee of my Ministry in Parliament. The amendments proposed to the Civil Procedure Code in order reduce the backlog of cases also identified Pre-trial Procedure being introduced as a new feature, a separate feature of judicial mediation. That particular aspect of judicial mediation came in for some opposition by the Bar Association of Sri Lanka. They have officially taken up the position that they cannot agree to judicial mediation at this juncture.

So, having considered that option, the Ministry has tried to drop that portion and now we have submitted the Civil Procedure Code with the rest of the amendments including the pre-trial judges and various other procedures involved. This has now been submitted to the Cabinet Subcommittee on Legislation. The Cabinet Subcommittee on Legislation also met recently and has approved the Civil Procedure Code Amendments. It will shortly come back to the Cabinet and thereafter, we will send it to the Legal Draftsman and present it to Parliament.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Regarding a separate office in the divisional secretariats in every division, in certain divisional secretariats they have agreed to allow them to use their space and in some there are space constraints. We have now begun the process and hopefully within a very short period, we can have a separate area allocated for Mediation Board activities. . ( . ) (The Hon. Ajith P. Perera) , . . . ?

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) To recruit stenographers, the Ministry of Public Administration has set up a criteria where we have to conduct examinations; they have to get through the examination and thereafter, interviews are conducted. This is done in keeping with the circular issued by the Ministry of Public Administration. Recently too, an examination was conducted and depending on the number of successful candidates, we will hold the interviews and recruit the stenographers necessary for the courts. :

( ) (The Deputy Speaker) . ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Mr. Deputy Speaker, I had also given notice of a matter of public importance under Standing Order No. 23(2), which relates to the issue that arose at the Dambulla Mosque and has appeared in the front page of today's Daily Mirror.
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Minister, could you raise that tomorrow?

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Sir, I do agree that there is an issue relating to giving prior notice. But, there is a matter of principle here and I would like to clarify that. I am not at cross-purposes with your decision to ask me to raise it tomorrow. But then, there is a matter of principle relating to raising a matter of public importance though giving notice to the subject Minister, is an important issue.
If you take Standing Order No. 19, after Questions of Privilege, there are two items before Public Business in order of precedence. One is, I quote:
"Motions at the commencement of Public Business not requiring notice.
Motions at the commencement of Public Business for which notice is required.
Then, Notices are dealt with under Standing Order No. 23, where there is this proviso which states, I quote:

Provided, however, a question relating to a matter of public importance may be asked at the conclusion of questions by the Leader of the Opposition or a leader of a recognized political party after due notice has been given to the Minister concerned.

The issue is regarding "due notice". The Secretary-General interprets "due notice" as one full days notice or rather, notice given on the previous day. But, if the subject Minister has been told that I am going to raise it today, that should be enough. That is where the "due notice" issue comes up. Party Leaders or the Leader of the Opposition must have the right to raise any matter of public importance after due notice. But, do not limit it to notice given on the previous day. Even in the morning, if I tell the Minster concerned that I am going raise it, that should be sufficient. That is the matter of principle I want to raise, Sir.

( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Minister, I take your point. All this time, as of practice, this Parliament has recognized only four Leaders as Party Leaders. So, this issue can be decided by the Party Leaders at the Meeting which will be summoned tomorrow. I am referring to the practice of this Parliament as at today. Therefore, the Party Leaders can take a decision tomorrow.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Sir, this is a much more serious and preposterous matter that you are raising. It is a much more serious issue to say that I am not considered as a Party Leader. That is absolutely preposterous and I simply cannot agree with that position.

( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Minister, let that be taken up at the Party Leaders Meeting tomorrow. I am informing this House of the practices that this House has been following to date. But, the Party Leaders have the authority to determine on it at the Party Leaders Meeting, which will be convened tomorrow.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) I am also a Member of the Party Leaders Meeting. Then, what is the reason for my name to be included in the Party Leaders list and why have you allocated me a front seat here? What nonsense is this?
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) That will be determined tomorrow at the Party Leaders Meeting.

( ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe) Hon. Deputy Speaker - ( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Leader of the Opposition, please. ( ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe) Sir, I know the dilemma the Hon. Minister is in with regard to the issue and what has happened. I think that is a matter that has to be raised. Having said that, I agree with you, Sir, that there are only four Parties recognized in this House. I think the remedy for the Hon. Minister is to take this matter up in the Cabinet. . . , . . There is a sense of collective responsibility. I am not talking of the substance. I know what the Hon. Minister is talking about; we also have certain concerns. But, on this particular issue, what I say is, there are only four parties and it is a matter that has to be really taken up in the Cabinet.
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) That will be taken up at the Party Leaders Meeting. Hon. Leader of the Opposition, this is not the forum to discuss it.
( ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe) I am only supporting you, Sir. It is a matter to be taken up in the Cabinet. And, if he does not agree with their decision, he must resign. - [Interruption.]

( ) (The Deputy Speaker) This is not the forum to discuss that issue. Hon. Minster, you raise your matter tomorrow at the Party Leaders Meeting, of which you are also a Member. Then, this issue will be determined there. Thank you very much.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Sir, let me also tell the Hon. Leader of the Opposition that it shows the kind of desperation he is in, trying to get us to relinquish office in Government. I am not here to give him solace for the kind of desperation that he is in today. He seems to be so desperate to get us out of Government. I did not know that he would say something so undignified in order to demean my status as a party leader, which he himself has recognized by a Memorandum of Understanding signed with him at times of elections. How dare he says that he has decided that only four Party Leaders are in this House. When his Government and this Government have allocated us front row seats and letters have been issued to us as leaders of political parties, how dare he says this.

( ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe) Sir, I have no intention of speaking anymore, except to say that once the Hon. Speaker has recognized parties, that is the correct position. We are different parties recognized by the Commissioner of Elections. - [Interruption.] No, no. There are a number of parties recognized by the Commissioner of Elections. But, -
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Leader of the Opposition, can we take this up at the Party Leaders' Meeting as the time is 2.25 p.m. now?

( ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe) No, no, Sir, there is something else that was said about me. There is a difference to what he said. What we are talking here is about the parties we contested under. So, that is a matter to be taken up in the Cabinet. I have to say - I sympathize with him - that this is not the forum. The forum is the Cabinet. Maybe, the Hon. Minister does not want to leave the Cabinet at all. That is his prerogative, not mine; I cannot tell you that. All I am

saying is, the Hon. Minister has a problem. I know the problem; I know the substance of it. Maybe, we agree with him on some of the matters. But, it does not mean that the Speakers Ruling can be challenged in any way. The normal principle of collective responsibility is to take it up in the Cabinet and then, you abide by the final decision of the Cabinet. That is all. I have nothing else to say.
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Thank you very much, Hon. Leader of the Opposition.
